list.title: Question 1
list.content: Identify the correct row in the table regarding the formation of vesicles when lipids are mixed with water.Structure of vesicleFeature of fatty acid tailMembrane formationA.\hspace{1em}monolayerhydrophilicspontaneousB.\hspace{1em}bilayerhydrophobicspontaneousC.\hspace{1em}monolayerhydrophilicinducedD.\hspace{1em}bilayerhydrophobicinduced
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:When lipids are mixed with water, they spontaneously form bilayers because the hydrophobic tails of the lipids interact with each other, and the hydrophilic heads interact with the water. This leads to the formation of a lipid bilayer, which is the structure of a vesicle. This is a spontaneous process driven by the amphipathic nature of the lipid molecules. Therefore,Choice Bis correct.The membrane around the vesicle is not a monolayer of phospholipids (Choices AandC) because the hydrophilic phosphate heads of the outer layer naturally point outwards into the surrounding aqueous solution, while the heads of the inner layer point inwards to the aqueous contents. The fatty acid tails are hydrophobic, not hydrophilic (Choices AandC), and they align in the centre of the bilayer to minimise exposure to water.Additionally, vesicles are not induced to form in this context (Choices CandD) since the amphipathic nature of phospholipids leads to their self-assembly into bilayers, making external input or induction unnecessary.

list.title: Question 2
list.content: Which of the following statements are reasons that RNA is believed to be the first genetic material?I.RNA can form spontaneously when nucleotides are presentII.RNA contains ribose as its sugarIII.RNA can function as enzymesA.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and IIIC.\hspace{1em}II and IIID.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:RNA is believed to be a potential candidate for the first genetic material due to its ability to form spontaneously from nucleotides (Statement I). RNA molecules, known as ribozymes, can catalyze chemical reactions (Statement III), including their own replication. This is a key reason why RNA is considered the first genetic material—unlike DNA, RNA can both store information and perform enzymatic functions, making it a strong candidate for early life processes.Choice Bis correct.Choice Aonly includedStatement Iand notIII, so it is incorrect.While it is true that RNA contains ribose as its sugar component (Statement II), the presence of ribose is not a primary reason for RNA being considered the first genetic material. Both RNA and DNA contain sugars in their structures, but the key point in favour of RNA as the first genetic material is its ability to form spontaneously.Choices CandDincludedStatement IIand so are incorrect.

list.title: Question 3
list.content: Which statement(s) is/are a necessary requirement for the evolution of the first cells?I.DNA having the ability to catalyse reactionsII.Polymerisation of carbon compoundsIII.Spontaneous formation of vesiclesA.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyB.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:There is evidence that simple carbon-containing molecules were present on Earth, millions of years ago, however, for early cells to evolve, they would have needed these simple molecules to form more complex structures such as polysaccharides and polynucleotides (Statement II). Phospholipids can spontaneously form vesicles (Statement III) or microspheres (microscopic hollow spheres made from a phospholipid bilayer), which resemble the plasma membrane of a small cell, this would allow for early cells to develop a different internal chemical environment from their surroundings.Choice Bis correct.DNA cannot catalyse reactions,Statement Iis incorrect.Choices A, CandDare incorrect as they includeStatement I.

list.title: Question 5
list.content: Why is it difficult for scientists to test hypotheses about the origin of the first cells?A.\hspace{1em}The conditions on pre-biotic Earth cannot be accurately replicatedB.\hspace{1em}The first cells are still alive, but are hard to studyC.\hspace{1em}Fossil evidence of protocells is abundant but hard to interpretD.\hspace{1em}Protocells did not contain nucleic acids
list.markScheme:
AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Scientists face significant challenges replicating the exact environmental conditions of early Earth because our understanding of its atmosphere, temperature, pressure, and chemical composition billions of years ago is limited;Choice Ais correct.The first cells appeared billions of years ago and are now extinct. Modern cells are descendants but not the original first cells;Choice Bis incorrect.
There is very limited or no direct fossil evidence of the first protocells because they were microscopic, soft-bodied, and lacked durable structures that fossilise well. The lack, rather than the abundance, of fossil evidence is a key challenge to testing the hypothesis about the origin of the first cells;Choice Cis incorrect.
Current scientific understanding strongly supports that protocells contained early forms of genetic material, such as RNA molecules. RNA is believed to have played a dual role as both a genetic material and a catalyst (ribozymes), making it central to hypotheses like the RNA world hypothesis.
Nucleic acids are crucial because they enable self-replication and heredity, essential for the evolution of life.Choice Dcontradicts the accepted hypotheses and is therefore incorrect.

list.title: Question 6
list.content: Which role of RNA supports the hypothesis that it acted as the first genetic material?A.\hspace{1em}It functions as a primer during transcriptionB.\hspace{1em}It functions as an enzyme used by ribosomesC.\hspace{1em}It serves as a template for polypeptide synthesisD.\hspace{1em}It transports amino acids during translation
list.markScheme: BSample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:RNA has the ability to self-replicate and can also act as an enzyme. These two properties contribute to the hypothesis that RNA was the first genetic material, rather than DNA.Choice Bis correct.Choice Ais incorrect, as transcription does not involve primers.Choice Cis incorrect, as RNA’s role as a template for polypeptide synthesis does not contribute to the hypothesis that it was the first genetic material.Choice Dis wrong, as RNA’s role in transporting amino acids during translation does not contribute to the hypothesis that it was the first genetic material.

list.title: Question 7
list.content: Which property of ribozymes is believed to have identified RNA as the first genetic material, ahead of DNA?A.\hspace{1em}StructuralB.\hspace{1em}SyntheticC.\hspace{1em}CatalyticD.\hspace{1em}Physical
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Cis correct because ribozymes are lengths of RNA that have catalytic properties (hence the ‘-zymes’ suffix, like the in word ‘en-zymes’). Some reactions that are thought to have been catalysed by ribozymes are the formation of peptide bonds during protein synthesis, a feature of ribosomal RNA in all species, not just in early life forms. This catalytic property also helps to explain how DNA first formed and became the basic unit of inheritance, with proteins carrying out most of the catalytic activity in cells.Choice Ais incorrect because RNA does not give any structural properties to cells or organelles that contain it.Choice Bis incorrect because RNA has a role in protein synthesis, but it does not explain how RNA may have pre-dated DNA as the first genetic material.Choice Dis incorrect because the physical properties of RNA and ribozymes are irrelevant to their role in early life development.

list.title: Question 8
list.content: Evidence suggests that the last universal common ancestor was nitrogen-fixing. Which biological molecule might it have incorporated nitrogen into?A.\hspace{1em}StarchB.\hspace{1em}DNA nucleotideC.\hspace{1em}Ribose sugarD.\hspace{1em}Fatty acid
list.markScheme: BSample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:A DNA nucleotide is made up of a phosphate group, a nitrogenous base and a pentose sugar. Nitrogen is an essential component of the bases.Choice Bis correct.Starch, ribose sugar, and fatty acids do not contain nitrogen.Choices A, CandDare incorrect.

list.title: Question 9
list.content: All organisms evolve through natural selection. Which of the following is a direct effect of natural selection on living organisms?A.\hspace{1em}It promotes the accumulation of beneficial traits in organismsB.\hspace{1em}It allowed the last universal common ancestor to outcompete other organisms within one generationC.\hspace{1em}It allows organisms that are best adapted to their environment to surviveD.\hspace{1em}It explains how life began on Earth
list.markScheme: CSample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:Natural selection allows organisms that are best adapted to their environment to survive and pass on their genes;Choice Cis correct.Promoting the accumulation of beneficial traits in organisms is a consequence of natural selection, not the direct effect. As organisms with beneficial traits survive and reproduce more, those traits become more common in the population over time. Natural selection is driven by random mutations that may or may not benefit an organism;Choice Ais incorrect. Although natural selection via evolution did allow the last universal common ancestor to outcompete other organisms, it is likely to have been a gradual process that did not occur within one generation;Choice Bis incorrect. Natural selection does not address the origin of life itself; it explains how life changes and evolves after it has already begun. ;Choice Dis incorrect.

list.title: Question 10
list.content: Which statement(s) provide evidence for the common ancestry of all existing forms of cellular life?I.The universality of the genetic codeII.The machinery for protein synthesisIII.Use of ATP as a common energy currencyA.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Statements I, IIandIIIare true, makingChoice Dthe correct answer to the question.The universality of the genetic code(Statement I)suggests that all modern organisms inherited this code from a single common ancestor. The nearly identical genetic code across all known forms of life. implies that the code was established very early in the history of life and has been conserved through billions of years of evolution. If different forms of life had arisen independently, it is highly unlikely that they would all use the same genetic code.The machinery for protein synthesis,(Statement II)which includes ribosomes, transfer RNA (tRNA), and messenger RNA (mRNA), is remarkably conserved across all forms of cellular life. This high degree of similarity suggests that these complex molecular mechanisms were inherited from a common ancestor, known as the Last Universal Common Ancestor (LUCA).ATP as a common energy currency(Statement III)used by organisms as diverse as bacteria, archaea, and eukaryotes suggests that this energy system was established early in the evolutionary history of life and inherited from a single ancestral organism. If different forms of life had evolved independently, it is unlikely that they would all rely on the same molecule for energy, reinforcing the idea of a shared origin.

list.title: Question 13
list.content: When early lifeforms first emerged on Earth, the levels of UV radiation were much higher than they are today. How did higher levels of UV radiation affect the conditions of the early Earth?A.\hspace{1em}Provided energy for photosynthesis, so plants produced higher levels of oxygenB.\hspace{1em}Broke down gases into smaller moleculesC.\hspace{1em}Mutated DNA nucleotide sequences so that a variety of polypeptides were formedD.\hspace{1em}Caused volcanoes to release gases into the atmosphere
list.markScheme: BSample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:The high levels of UV radiation broke down gases in the early atmosphere, which provided smaller, highly reactive molecules that eventually formed the building blocks of life, such as amino acids, peptides and ribose.Choice Bis correct.Billions of years ago, there were no plants, and high levels of UV can affect plants adversely by damaging DNA;Choice Ais incorrect. Although UV radiation affects DNA, DNA was not thought to be present when the first life forms appeared;Choice Cis incorrect. UV radiation did not cause volcanoes to release gases into the atmosphere, this was caused by Earth cooling down after the Hadean aeon;Choice Dis incorrect.

Created with BioRender.com]How did Pasteur's experiments with swan-necked flasks provide convincing evidence to falsify the concept of spontaneous generation?I.\hspace{1em}Broth in flask X grew cloudy due to dust and microbes being trapped in the neck, suggesting that even filtered air can induce microbial growth.II.\hspace{.7em}Broth in flask Y remained clear, indicating no spontaneous microbial growth, as the sealed environment prevented any external contamination.III.\hspace{.4em}Broth in flask Z remained clear, proving that exposure to air alone does not lead to microbial growth.A.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}II onlyC.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Statement I is not true. In Pasteur's experiment, the broth in flask X, which had a swan neck, remained clear because the swan neck prevented dust and airborne microbes from reaching the broth while still allowing air to pass through. The dust and microbes were trapped in the bends of the swan neck and did not contaminate the broth.Statement II is true. Flask Y was sterilised and then sealed. The absence of microbial growth in this sealed environment supports the idea that microorganisms are not spontaneously generated from the broth but must be introduced from an external source.Statement III is not true. Pasteur's experiment showed that microbial growth occurred when the swan neck of flask Z was broken off, exposing the previously sterilised broth to the air without any barrier. This demonstrated that microorganisms in the air were responsible for the growth in the broth, not spontaneous generation.As only Statement II is true, answer choice B is the correct answer to this question.

list.title: Question 16
list.content: Enzymes are needed to replicate and transcribe DNA. Ribosomes are needed to translate the DNA into enzymes. According to the “RNA world” hypothesis, what problem does this present for the first lifeforms to evolve on Earth?A.\hspace{1em}Early life forms could not catalyse reactions.B.\hspace{1em}Early life forms could not self-replicate.C.\hspace{1em}Early life forms were unable to produce proteins.D.\hspace{1em}Early lifeforms did not have cell membranes.
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Cis correct because early life forms likely had neither ribosomes nor enzymes and therefore could not produce proteins. The “RNA world” hypothesis suggests that early life forms were believed to have used ribozymes (RNA molecules with catalytic activity) to catalyse essential reactions.Choice Ais incorrect because the ability to catalyse metabolic reactions is thought to be a requirement for early life forms.Choice Bis incorrect because self-replication is also a basic requirement for all living things.Choice Dis incorrect because early life forms would have been unicellular, and all cells need a membrane of some kind to maintain structure and chemical gradients.

list.title: Question 17
list.content: In the early 19th century, vitalism was a widely accepted theory. This theory suggested that organic compounds, those found in living organisms, could only be produced through a "vital force" present in living matter.What was the role of urea in falsifying the theory of vitalism?A.\hspace{1em}Urea is produced by kidneys, indicating that living things can make organic compounds.B.\hspace{1em}Urea can be produced in laboratories, indicating that living things cannot synthesize organic compounds.C.\hspace{1em}Urea can be produced in laboratories, indicating that not only living things can synthesize organic compounds.D.\hspace{1em}Urea is produced by the kidneys, indicating that not only laboratories can make organic compounds.
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The theory of vitalism states that only living things can synthesise organic molecules. In 1953 Miller and Urey set up apparatus to simulate the conditions believed to be present on early Earth. Using these apparatus, they managed to produce urea, an organic compound, in the laboratory, which falsified this theory of vitalism. ThereforeChoice Cis correct.The fact that urea is produced by the kidneys (Choices AandD) does not falsify the theory of vitalism but rather supports it. The production of urea in laboratories does not mean it cannot be synthesised by living things (Choice B).
